title: Ticket #4121: Concurrency limits and partitionable slots lead to overclaiming limits
description:
Problem 1: When a partitionable slot is claimed by a job with a concurrency limit, the newly created dynamic slot will use the concurrency limit (correct), as will the partitionable slot (wrong). The next time the partitionable slot creates a dynamic slot, the partitionable slot will lose the concurrency limit (sort of correct), but the new dynamic slot will gain it (wrong). There is no workaround at this time.

Problem 2: Claim reuse doesn't respect concurrency limits. At the very least, if a non-concurrency using job shows up after a concurrency using job, the slot will continue to use the concurrency limit, chewing up the limit despite not having any use for it. Current workaround: CLAIM_WORKLIFE=0 to disable claim reuse.

Reproduction

  1. tar xvzf /p/condor/public/binaries/v8.0/8.0.5/condor-8.0.5-x86_64_RedHat6-stripped.tar.gz
  2. cd condor-8.0.5-x86_64_RedHat6-stripped
  3. ./condor_install --make-personal-condor
  4. source condor.sh / condor.csh
  5. Append to local.$HOSTNAME/condor_config.local: 
    NEGOTIATOR_DEBUG=D_ACCOUNTANT
FOO_LIMIT=4
NUM_CPUS=8
SLOT_TYPE_1=mem=100%,cpu=100%,disk=100%,swap=100%
SLOT_TYPE_1_PARTITIONABLE=TRUE
NUM_SLOTS_TYPE_1=1
  6. condor_master
  7. Create submit.foo containing: 
    executable=/bin/sleep
arguments=60
concurrency_limits=FOO
queue 5
  8. Create submit.basic containing: 
    executable=/bin/sleep
arguments=60
queue 50
  9. condor_submit submit.foo. Wait a little bit until a job starts.
  10. condor_status -af concurrencylimits name globaljobid . Observe that the partitionable slot is using foo, when it shouldn't be. For example: 
    foo slot1@puffin.cs.wisc.edu undefined
foo slot1_1@puffin.cs.wisc.edu puffin.cs.wisc.edu#13.0#1386973329
  11. Wait for the next negotiation cycle. Observe in the negotiator log that it had 1 claim on foo before, now it has 2, which is wrong. Presumably the partitionable slot is being counted. 
    12/13/13 16:54:37 Previous Limits --
12/13/13 16:54:37   Limit: foo = 1.000000
12/13/13 16:54:37 IncrementLimit(foo)
12/13/13 16:54:37 IncrementLimit(foo)
12/13/13 16:54:37 Current Limits --
12/13/13 16:54:37   Limit: foo = 2.000000
  12. condor_submit submit.basic; condor_reschedule
  13. condor_status -af concurrencylimits name globaljobid . Observe that one of the slots running a basic job is marked as claiming a foo resource, which is wrong. Also observe that only a single foo job can match each cycle, while all of the basic jobs case, which might be wrong. For example (here 14.* is foo, while 15.* is basic): 
    foo slot1_1@puffin.cs.wisc.edu puffin.cs.wisc.edu#14.0#1386973495
foo slot1_2@puffin.cs.wisc.edu puffin.cs.wisc.edu#14.1#1386973495
foo slot1_3@puffin.cs.wisc.edu puffin.cs.wisc.edu#15.0#1386973507
undefined slot1_4@puffin.cs.wisc.edu puffin.cs.wisc.edu#15.1#1386973507
undefined slot1_5@puffin.cs.wisc.edu puffin.cs.wisc.edu#15.2#1386973507
undefined slot1_6@puffin.cs.wisc.edu puffin.cs.wisc.edu#15.3#1386973507
undefined slot1_7@puffin.cs.wisc.edu puffin.cs.wisc.edu#15.4#1386973507
undefined slot1_8@puffin.cs.wisc.edu puffin.cs.wisc.edu#15.5#1386973507
  14. Eventually the foo jobs will complete. Observe that basic job slot that erroneously claimed a foo resource continues to do so, even as later jobs cycle through it. This is wrong (and probably the result of re-using a claim). Example: 
    undefined slot1@puffin.cs.wisc.edu undefined
undefined slot1_1@puffin.cs.wisc.edu puffin.cs.wisc.edu#15.26#1386973507
undefined slot1_2@puffin.cs.wisc.edu puffin.cs.wisc.edu#15.27#1386973507
foo slot1_3@puffin.cs.wisc.edu puffin.cs.wisc.edu#15.28#1386973507
undefined slot1_4@puffin.cs.wisc.edu puffin.cs.wisc.edu#15.29#1386973507
undefined slot1_5@puffin.cs.wisc.edu puffin.cs.wisc.edu#15.30#1386973507
undefined slot1_6@puffin.cs.wisc.edu puffin.cs.wisc.edu#15.31#1386973507
undefined slot1_7@puffin.cs.wisc.edu puffin.cs.wisc.edu#15.32#1386973507
undefined slot1_8@puffin.cs.wisc.edu puffin.cs.wisc.edu#15.33#1386973507
